sub_topic: Interpolation and extrapolation of data using Lagrange polynomials
message_1:
Suppose we have obtained the following set of data $(x,y)$:

$$(0,1), (1,3), (3,7), (4,8)$$

Use Lagrange interpolation to approximate the value of $y$ when $x=2$.
message_2:
To approximate the value of $y$ when $x=2$ using Lagrange interpolation, we will use the formula:

$$L(x) = \sum_{i=0}^n y_i \cdot l_i(x)$$

where $l_i(x) = \prod_{j=0, j\neq i}^n \frac{x-x_j}{x_i-x_j}$.

In our case, we have 4 data points, so $n=3$. Let's calculate the $l_i(x)$ values for $i=0,1,2,3$:

$l_0(x) = \frac{(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)}{(0-1)(0-3)(0-4)} = \frac{(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)}{24}$

$l_1(x) = \frac{(x-0)(x-3)(x-4)}{(1-0)(1-3)(1-4)} = \frac{x(x-3)(x-4)}{-6}$

$l_2(x) = \frac{(x-0)(x-1)(x-4)}{(3-0)(3-1)(3-4)} = \frac{x(x-1)(x-4)}{6}$

$l_3(x) = \frac{(x-0)(x-1)(x-3)}{(4-0)(4-1)(4-3)} = \frac{x(x-1)(x-3)}{-12}$

Now, we can calculate $L(x)$:

$$L(x) = y_0 \cdot l_0(x) + y_1 \cdot l_1(x) + y_2 \cdot l_2(x) + y_3 \cdot l_3(x)$$

$$L(x) = 1 \cdot \frac{(x-1)(x-3)(x-4)}{24} + 3 \cdot \frac{x(x-3)(x-4)}{-6} + 7 \cdot \frac{x(x-1)(x-4)}{6} + 8 \cdot \frac{x(x-1)(x-3)}{-12}$$

Now, we can find the value of $L(2)$:

$$L(2) = 1 \cdot \frac{(2-1)(2-3)(2-4)}{24} + 3 \cdot \frac{2(2-3)(2-4)}{-6} + 7 \cdot \frac{2(2-1)(2-4)}{6} + 8 \cdot \frac{2(2-1)(2-3)}{-12}$$

$$L(2) = 1 \cdot \frac{(-1)(-2)(-2)}{24} + 3 \cdot \frac{2(-1)(-2)}{-6} + 7 \cdot \frac{2(1)(-2)}{6} + 8 \cdot \frac{2(1)(-1)}{-12}$$

$$L(2) = \frac{4}{24} - \frac{12}{6} - \frac{28}{6} + \frac{16}{12}$$

$$L(2) = \frac{1}{6} - 2 - \frac{14}{3} + \frac{4}{3}$$

$$L(2) = -2 + \frac{1}{6} - \frac{10}{3}$$

$$L(2) = -2 - \frac{10}{3} + \frac{1}{6}$$

$$L(2) = -\frac{12}{6} - \frac{20}{6} + \frac{1}{6}$$

$$L(2) = -\frac{31}{6}$$

So, the approximate value of $y$ when $x=2$ using Lagrange interpolation is $L(2) = -\frac{31}{6}$.
